docs.snippet: The bill that President Clinton signed this week penalizing foreign companies doing business with Cuba illustrates two of the most controversial trends in American trade policy.         The measure, which set off howls of protest from American...
docs.lead_paragraph: The bill that President Clinton signed this week penalizing foreign companies doing business with Cuba illustrates two of the most controversial trends in American trade policy. The measure, which set off howls of protest from American trading partners, represents the latest of many attempts to extend the reach of United States law beyond the country's borders.

headline.main: Ire and Votes: U.S. Vents Its Rage at Cuba In Trade Law

docs.snippet: ONE of the most perplexing political questions of the late 20th century is how new democracies should punish deposed dictators and their associates. Victims cry for justice, but leaders of new regimes must decide to what extent it is possible, moral...
docs.lead_paragraph: ONE of the most perplexing political questions of the late 20th century is how new democracies should punish deposed dictators and their associates. Victims cry for justice, but leaders of new regimes must decide to what extent it is possible, moral or prudent to pursue evildoers of the past. This question emerged in Chile, Argentina and Uruguay during the mid-1980's, when murderous military dictatorships gave way to freely elected civilian governments. Eastern European countries faced it a few years later, after the collapse of Communist regimes. More recently, South Africa and South Korea have brought high-ranking officials of past governments to trial in connection with bloody crimes.

headline.main: Word for Word/On Trial in Germany;We Weren't Following Orders, But the Currents of the Cold War

docs.snippet: Shaken by election campaigning in the United States that has indicated voter  discontent over breaking down trade barriers, trade ministers from 34 North and  South American nations meeting here this week decided they would begin discussing the...
docs.lead_paragraph: Shaken by election campaigning in the United States that has indicated voter discontent over breaking down trade barriers, trade ministers from 34 North and South American nations meeting here this week decided they would begin discussing the structure of a Free Trade Area of the Americas next year. A poll released here by the Bank of Boston recently showed that most respondents in the United States thought business, rather than consumers, benefited from free trade, and that opening borders cost them jobs.

headline.main: Unity Cracking as American Nations Meet on an Economic Zone

docs.snippet: The Academy Awards show got a new exclamation point (it was billed by ABC as  a "Special Presentation!") and other excitable touches this year. The show began with worrisome hints that its new producer, Quincy Jones, would stop at nothing  to make...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Academy Awards show got a new exclamation point (it was billed by ABC as a "Special Presentation!") and other excitable touches this year. The show began with worrisome hints that its new producer, Quincy Jones, would stop at nothing to make this staid ceremony more user-friendly, and might outdo even Hollywood in pandering to trashy popular tastes. So there was Oprah Winfrey greeting luminaries outside the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion, treating last year's best supporting actress, Dianne Wiest, like a Miss America emeritus. ("You're giving up the throne tonight. Is that hard to do?") Subjected to a hard-hitting question from Ms. Winfrey, Elisabeth Shue admitted that a best actress nomination had not changed her and she still loved her dog.

headline.main: Energy, Gallantry, Graphics And Glamour at the Oscars

docs.snippet: WHEN "AMERICA" IS used as a synonym for the United States, many Latin Americans object, arguing that the term should apply equally from Patagonia to Canada. In this spirit, perhaps, the American Composers Orchestra is presenting  "Sonidos de las...
docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN "AMERICA" IS used as a synonym for the United States, many Latin Americans object, arguing that the term should apply equally from Patagonia to Canada. In this spirit, perhaps, the American Composers Orchestra is presenting "Sonidos de las Americas," an annual series dedicated to music from Latin America, now in its third year. "Sonidos" is a festival of performances and more. This year dedicated to Brazil, it opens this afternoon with Sergio and Odair Assad playing music for two guitars at the unsinkable Thalia Spanish Theater in Sunnyside, Queens, and ends next Sunday with the orchestra performing at Carnegie Hall. There are also concerts during the week at Weill Recital Hall and other sites in Manhattan, the Bronx and Queens.

headline.main: Turning an Ear To Other Americas

docs.snippet: Negotiators from 51 countries are racing against the clock at the World Trade Organization in Geneva this month, hoping to meet their self-imposed deadline of April 30 for an agreement on liberalizing trade in telecommunications.         At stake is...
docs.lead_paragraph: Negotiators from 51 countries are racing against the clock at the World Trade Organization in Geneva this month, hoping to meet their self-imposed deadline of April 30 for an agreement on liberalizing trade in telecommunications. At stake is the future of the global telecommunications industry, and possibly of the World Trade Organization itself. The goal of the talks is to open domestic telecommunications markets to foreign companies, potentially saving consumers billions of dollars. But an agreement would also put many sluggish national telephone companies at risk of being trampled by more efficient foreign competitors.

headline.main: Global Talks Covering Phones Near Deadline

docs.snippet: WHEN a product is so common that it is used as a prop in a television show stunt, is it a sign that its potential for new uses has been played out?         That is one of the questions facing investors looking at Velcro Industries N.V., the Dutch...
docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN a product is so common that it is used as a prop in a television show stunt, is it a sign that its potential for new uses has been played out? That is one of the questions facing investors looking at Velcro Industries N.V., the Dutch company that makes those ubiquitous Velcro sticky strip fasteners. Used in everything from clothing to spacecraft -- not to mention the wall-jumping stunt on "The Late Show With David Letterman" -- the fastener has even made a brief appearance in a Presidential election. In 1992, in a play on Ronald Reagan's nickname as the Teflon President, political commentators dubbed George Bush "Velcro man" for accepting the blame for so many things.

headline.main: It Keeps Your Pants On. But Can It Fatten Your Wallet?

docs.snippet: Overnight, the shadow of another coup in Paraguay was swept away, but the relief of the people here is tempered by outrage over the compromise the civilian Government made to escape the threat.         The army commander, Gen. Lino Cesar Oviedo, who...
docs.lead_paragraph: Overnight, the shadow of another coup in Paraguay was swept away, but the relief of the people here is tempered by outrage over the compromise the civilian Government made to escape the threat. The army commander, Gen. Lino Cesar Oviedo, who had refused a presidential order to resign and taken refuge in an army barracks, agreed to leave his post, President Juan Carlos Wasmosy announced late Tuesday night in a nationally televised address. But the general's condition for resigning was that he be named Defense Minister.

headline.main: Paraguay Averts a Military Coup, but the Deal Outrages Many

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: COUPS D'ETAT AND ATTEMPTED COUPS D'ETAT

docs.snippet: The week after the White House settled its budget squabbles with Congress is  a good time to assess President Clinton's stewardship of the economy. He came into office promising to bring a consensus style of policy-making to the White House -- no...
docs.lead_paragraph: The week after the White House settled its budget squabbles with Congress is a good time to assess President Clinton's stewardship of the economy. He came into office promising to bring a consensus style of policy-making to the White House -- no longer would a budget director like Richard Darman, who served under President Bush, bully everyone in sight. He also promised to direct Federal spending away from wasteful programs and toward future-looking investments in training people. How has he done? The record is mixed. He had many small successes and, in health and welfare reform, a few spectacular failures. On balance, Mr. Clinton did little harm and allowed the economy to prosper. That is not an exciting grade sheet. But it is a responsible one.
